definitions.definition: used to say that it is possible for somebody/something to do something, or for something to happen

examples.text: I can run fast.
Can you call back tomorrow?
He couldn't answer the question.
The stadium can be emptied in four minutes.
I can't promise anything, but I'll do what I can.
Please let us know if you cannot attend the meeting.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody knows how to do something

examples.text: She can speak Spanish.
Can you cook?
I could drive a car before I left school.
She could feel the warnth of the sun on her face.
I can hear music.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody is allowed to do something

examples.text: You can take the car, if you want.
We can't wear jeans at work.

definitions.definition: used to ask permission to do something

examples.text: Can I read your newspaper?
Can I take you home?

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to help you

examples.text: Can you help me with this box?
Can you feed the cat, please?
We can eat in a restaurant, if you like.
I can take the car if necessary.

definitions.definition: used in the negative for saying that you are sure something is not true

examples.text: That can't be Mary—she's in New York.
He can't have slept through all that noise.

definitions.definition: used to express doubt or surprise

examples.text: What can they be doing?
Can he be serious?
Where can she have put it?

definitions.definition: used to say what somebody/something is often like

examples.text: He can be very tactless sometimes.
It can be quite cold here in winter.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody must do something, usually when you are angry

examples.text: You can shut up or get out!

definitions.definition: used to say that you do not like something and are unwilling to accept it

examples.text: I can't be doing with people who complain all the time.
I can’t be doing with you moaning all the time.

definitions.definition: used to say that you are not able or willing to do something

examples.text: Sorry, no can do. I just don't have the time.

wordOrigin: Old English cunnan ‘know’ (in Middle English ‘know how to’), related to Dutch kunnen and German können; from an Indo-European root shared by Latin gnoscere ‘know’ and Greek gignōskein ‘know’.
